RESOLVED_ENTITIES.United States Court of Appeals for the F: United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia: United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the majority: United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: court that heard the case of United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia, where the jury was given a modified Allen charge after being deadlocked, and later returned a guilty verdict
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol: law enforcement agency involved in border surveillance, smuggling interception, and immigration inspections, with agents making stops based on reasonable suspicion, including assessments of individuals' appearances, and having specialized training for its agents
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court of Appeals for the F: appellate court considering the suppression motion on its merits, articulating principles for investigatory stops near the United States-Mexican border, providing guidance to jurors on their duties, relying on an agent's observation, providing guidance on probable cause to search vehicles, upholding the use of the modified Allen charge, and previously providing instructions in a case
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia: a legal case involving a challenge to the modified Allen charge given to the jury and a request for post-verdict discovery through juror depositions and interrogatories, with testimony reflecting obvious overloading of a pickup truck camper, currently being tried in court with a jury
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States-Mexican border: geographic boundary relevant to immigration and smuggling cases, with its proximity being a factor in justifying investigatory stops
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Interstate Highway 35: highway where the stop occurred, commonly used for smuggling of aliens
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Pena-Cantu: a legal case referenced in determining the justification for investigatory stops, and rejecting a general attack on the Allen charge as being inherently coercive
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Pacheco: a legal case referenced in determining the justification for investigatory stops, and affirming the rejection of a general attack on the Allen charge, with testimony from aliens implicating Maria De Jesus Garcia
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Orona-Sanchez: a legal case referenced in determining the justification for investigatory stops, and upholding the use of the modified Allen charge
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States: country where the court is located and where the case of United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia was heard
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Brignoni-Ponce standard: legal standard guiding reasonable suspicion for investigatory stops near the border, relevant to the context of United States v. Pena-Cantu and United States v. Orona-Sanchez
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S.-Mexican border: an international border relevant to immigration and smuggling cases, with its proximity being a factor in justifying investigatory stops
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court of Appeals for the F: appellate court making decisions regarding the justification of investigatory stops based on factors such as vehicle loading
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia: defendant in a legal case involving a challenge to the modified Allen charge given to the jury and a request for post-verdict discovery through juror depositions and interrogatories, with testimony from aliens implicating her, currently being tried in court
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Alfred Baron: border patrol agent involved in the stop and search of a pickup truck camper, who testified about the passengers' actions when a flashlight was shone into the vehicle, and is a native Spanish speaker
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Stanley Pruszenski: border patrol agent involved in the stop and search of a pickup truck camper, who testified about the passengers' actions when a light was shone into the vehicle, and has limited proficiency in Spanish
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Brignoni-Ponce: a court case referenced for distinguishing suspicious behavior
